BP = J . L . Campbell ( ed . ) , “ Proverbs from Barra collected by the late Neil Sinclair ” , SGS , x , pt . ii , ( 1965 ) , pp . 178 - 208 .
Carm . Gad . = Carmina Gadelica ( collected by Alexander Carmichael ) , 6 vols . , ( Edinburgh , 1900 - 71 ) .
Fr . Allan = J . L . Campbell ( ed . ) , Gaelic Words and Expressions from South Uist and Eriskay , collected by the Rev . Fr . Allan MacDonald of Eriskay ( Dublin , 1958 ) .
GP = H . Barron ( ed . ) , “ Some Proverbs from Glenurquhart ” , SGS , xii , pt . i ( 1971 ) , pp . 52 - 5 .
HN = Duncan Campbell ’ s contribution to “ Gaelic Proverbs Symposium ” , The Highland News , c . April 1897 .
LP = A . Matheson ( ed . ) , “ Some Proverbs and Proverbial Expressions from Lewis ” , The Journal of Celtic Studies , i , pp . 105 - 15 ( Baltimore , 1950 ) .
M = T . D . MacDonald ( ed . ) , Gaelic Proverbs and Proverbial Sayings ( Stirling , 1926 ) .
MFS = Margaret Fay Shaw , Folksongs and Folklore of South Uist ( London , 1955 ) .
N = M . MacInnes ( ed . ) , Nicolson ’ s Gaelic Proverbs ( Glasgow , 1951 ) .
RC = A . MacBain and J . Kennedy ( eds . ) . Reliquiae Celticae , 2 vols . ( Invemess , 1892 - 94 ) .
Contributions to a Dictionary of the Irish Language . See A Dictionary…
Dw . = E . Dwelly ( ed ) , An Illustrated Gaelic Dictionary .
FES = Fasti Ecclesiae Scoticanae , 9 vols . , ( Edinburgh , 1915 - 61 )
MacB . = A . MacBain ( ed . ) , An Etymological Dictionary of the Gaelic Language ( Stirling , 1911 ) .
SGS = Scottish Gaelic Studies , i ( Oxford , 1926 - 58 ; Aberdeen , 1961 - ) .
TGSI = The Transactions of the Gaelic Society of Inverness , i - .

In Gaelic itself , the regular term for a “ proverb ” is seanfhacal . This means literally “ an old word ” , which makes the point that what gives a saying its authority is not necessarily its content or its literary form , but the fact that it has been in use , and handed down , over many years . There are two other terms , which are used of “ proverbs ” in Gaelic : comhad , which is mainly a literary term , and which may approximate to the English “ maxim ” ; and gnàthfhocal , “ a customary saying ” , which is applied almost solely to the Proverbs of Solomon ( Gnàthfhocail Sholaimh ) in the Old Testament . In the Inner Hebrides , the collective term gràideanas ( “ what is said ” , from [a]g ràdh , the present participle of abair . “ say ” ) is often used of the general corpus of Gaelic sayings , although seanfhacail is also common . The only group of sayings not covered by the term seanfhacail
[Blank]
The most contemptible cow if the fold lows loudest on the hillside .

Cutting a rod to injure hiself .
( Uist )

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p:
Hogmanay , O Hogmanay , we come only once in the year ; we can be supplied with drink and remain sober ; we ’ ll take butter on bread , the pure barley bread and a spoonful of whisky ; so bring in the Hogmanay dainties !
( Uist )

[Cf . TGSI , xlix , p . 149 . Clearly one of the
“ Duain Challainn ” ( “ Hogmanay Rhymes ” ) which were recited by “ Gillean Callainn ” ( “ Hogmanay Lads ” ) who visited the houses of friends . See MFS , p . 23 . ]

The leg is short and the ford is deep .
( Uist )
The first wife is away , the second has come , and the same boots fits both of them .
The first glass for the host , the second for the guest .
Let the first Tuesday pass , the second Tuesday if need be ; on the third Tuesday , sow it in mud and mire .
[For what C . calls the Inverness version , and an explanation , see N 26 , 9 . Cf . M , no . 478 . ]

May the neap tide be frosty and the spring tide stormy !
( Uist )

The greater part is yet to grow , and the better part is yet to come .
( Inverness district )
The cuckoo and its attendant bird .

Growing towards the earth ( al . the grave ) .
( Uist )

It ’ s a vicious north wind which blows from hostile Harris .
( Uist )

Will you eat money , Maigean ?
( Uist )
You rogue ! You son of a rogue ! You grandson of a rogue ! You great grandson of a rogue ! You great great grandson of a rogue ! You great great great
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 119 , s . v . ròg . ]
His eyes are on the moon and his bottom on the hearth - stone .

Barking with the dog and bleating with the sheep .
( Argyll )
[i . e . , running with the hare and hunting with the hounds] .
A field of peat !
[From loose sheets within the covers of the MS . C . notes that the phrase was applied to a boaster . ]
He is eating my portion and smashing my mouth .
At his own discretion , like the lamb with the big tail .
In an easy position
[See Glossary s . v . giorran - guanach . Cf . N 356 , 11 . ]
For procuring limpets !
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 10 , s . v . bàirneach . ]
First in the wood and last in the bog .
The highest part of the plain and the lowest part of the hillside .

Alasdair of the two dinners .
( Uist )
Nurse your child this year and do your business next year .

The time to plough is when the earth begins to throw up the soil .
( Uist )

The rock cod which would not shirk a hook .
( Uist )
The person who would outwit the fox must rise early .
[Cf . RC2 , p . 476 . For traditions connected with the Appin Murder , see John Mackechnie ( ed . ) , The Dewar Manuscripts , Volume I , pp . l94 - 217 . ]
The person who lends loses his friend and his loan .
The person who lost his modesty and his manners lost all he had .
The person who spares his dinner knows where to get his supper .
The person who looks for a mote will get a mote .
The person who has eaten the dog may drink its juice .

The person who gets his own way will not die from sulking .
( Inverness district )
The person who lies will steal if need be .
Let the person who procured the venison wipe up the blood .
The person who possesses nothing will be low on the list .
The person who has no hand - net has a light basket .
The person who is bad at inviting is good at pointing out the road .
The person who goes to Iona will go there three times .
[See TGSI , xlv , p . 2 . ]
The person who comes uninvited will sit without being served .

I would go to the man who would come to me .
( Uist )

He who took her over will not let her back .
( Uist )

[The person who has the pitchers will get the coffers ( ? ) ]
( Perthshire )
[A person who has the initial advantages obtains what is best later on ( ? ) . C . translates , “ He who has possessions gets feasts ” . See Glossary s . v . ùraicean and àraicean . ]

Whoever the cap fits can wear it .
( Uist )
The Clyack sheaf stays with the man who finishes last .

Chan fhan a ’ Chailleach agam - sa a - nis .
The Clyack sheaf will not stay with me now .

[This custom was known as “ cur Cailliche ” ( “ planting a ‘ Cailleach ’ ” ) , and the person with whom the sheaf stayed finally was often ridiculed by his neighbours . Cf . N , pp . 415 - 6 ; Fr . Allan , p . 57 , s . v . Cailleach ; F . Marian MacNeill , The Silver Bough , ii , pp . 123 - 4 . ]
The person who does not hide his own fault will not hide that of his neighbour .
The person who does not sow in March will reap late .
If a man does not attend to his business , his business will not attend to him .
The man in the corner provides the peats .
The Big Hound , the Little Hound and the Surly Hound .
The burden should correspond to the strength of the back .
[See Glossary s . v . mùirnean . ]
The time to sow is a fortnight before May Day and a fortnight after it .
A blind man will find his way to the burial ground .
The only two who cannot marry are the priest and the Worthless One ( i . e . , the Devil ) .

[For further information on “ An Dall Mór ” , who was also a well known catechist , see A . MacDonald and A . MacDonald , Clan Donald , iii , pp . 590 - 1 ; W . Matheson ( ed . ) , The Songs of John MacCodrum , p . 208 , vii . ]
Two whitings boiled in the same way .
Ewan has the same twist in his nature as John .
The Lochcarron man is twisted , and he has a particular twist in his head .
[Cf . the Applecross variant :

An Carannach ’ s an car ann , car ’ na thòin ’ s car ’ na cheann .
The Lochcarron man is twisted ; he has a twist in his bottom and a twist in his head .
See no . 339 . ]
The morning of the grave lies far in the future .
The mist left by the old moon is dispersed by either snow or wind .
The clan is great , but its seed is prone to misfortune .

The dog , the man and the spear .
( Uist )
The worst dog Fionn ever had was “ Almost ” .
The danger which is behind us is a matter of envy .
Both sheets fastened to one thwart .

A sunny day follows a gloomy morning .
( Uist )

After winter thunder comes very good weather , or else atrocious weather [literally , “ weather of the seven elements ” ] .
( Uist )

Liquids for the young , solids for the adult [ ? ]
( Uist )
[See Glossary s . v . digh and iodh . ]
The last two to forsake you will be your dog and your sister ’ s son .
[C . comments , unconvincingly , that the saying “ appears to be of Fingalian origin , referring to Fionn and Diarmaid ” . ]

Let the broth the dog wouldn ’ t eat be given to Sallow John .
( Uist )
The young solan goose , the wild duck and the eel are the three witnesses of night .

[Alternatively , “ Giadh , lach is easgann . . . ” ( “ A goose , a wild duck and an eel . . . ” ) . Does this mean that these creatures are then most active , or that they are the most watchful creatures ? See Glossary s . v . teisd . ]
The time which follows an early Shrove - tide , more than any other feast , is unfortunate for a greedy man [ ? ] .

[The point may be that fasting comes earlier in the year than usual , and that a greedy man would prefer it to come later . Cf . N 172 , 10 ; Waifs and Strays , i , p . 46 . See Glossary s . v . beadaidh . ]

[To] the day you kill a deer , and the day you kill none .
( Mull )
The name belongs to the child who gets it in baptism .
What a man doesn ’ t like , he doesn ’ t hear .
What you don ’ t like , entrust to another .
What is fated will be unavoidable .
What is inside naturally comes out .
What an envious eye sees , an envious heart craves .
What sent the Devil to Hell was asking what he knew very well .

What Friday gets hold of in its mouth , it will keep .
( Uist and Lorn )
[Cf . BP , no . 33 ; Fr . Allan , p . 29 , s . v . Aoine . ]
What Wicked Donald does , Wicked Donald spoils .
What is paid for will not trouble us any more .

The foal that ought to be in the mare is in the gelding .
( Uist )
The seed we sow in youth , we shall reap in old age .
The tailor who does not knot his thread will lose his stitch .
The most polite name for a chilblain is a boot - sore .

Will you come or will you go , old wife , or will you eat heron ’ s flesh ?
( Uist )
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , pp . 48 - 9 , s . v . corr . ]

The three who are allowed to be hungry are a ploughman , a herd - boy and a wet nurse .
[See Glossary s . v . ban - altruim - cuim . ]
Some of the water at the source of a river [literally , “ in the higher land ” ] will be found at its mouth .

Rachel has a down - pour while others have dry weather .
( Uist )
[See Glossary s . v . Raogag . ]
Pride in the face of poverty .
[Does this mean that people should not feel ashamed of poverty , or that pride is opposed to poverty ? Cf . N 361 , 3 . See Glossary s . v . eirbhe . ]
When everyone is down on the old man , even the old wife is down on the old man .
When the husband is on fire , his wife ought to be water .

When Ben Cruachan is covered in mist , the River Orchy will not thirst .
( Argyll )
[Cf . TGSI , xlviii , p . 131 . ]

Thug na Fir - chlis fuil an raoir .
The Northern Lights drew blood last night .
[Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 126 , s . v . fir - chlisneach . ]
When the thong broke , Moses came .

When you get up , see that the grass rises after you .
( Argyll )

When the pin gives way , the staves will bend .
( Uist )
When the hoop ceased to go , my father would cease to drive it .
[The advice of the daughter of a Kintyre cooper to her preferred lover , when her father suggested that the suitor who could put a hoop on a barrel would get her hand . See TGSI , xlv , p . 3 . ]

When giving ceases , praise ceases .
( Uist )

When other people ’ s cows go dry , Dirty makes cheese then .
( Uist )
[Cf . N 333 , 5 . See TGSI , xlv , p . 3 ; Glossary s . v . Caclach . ]
When mountain grass and cotton - grass appear , food for cattle is to be found outside . ( Argyll )

When you come , you really do come !
( Lochness - side )
[Cf . TGSI , xlvi , p . 235 . ]

When Rocaburra comes into view , the world is doomed to destruction .
( Uist )

When a seal is the hound in the chase , the grilse will not escape .
[A reference to the speed of the seal . See Glossary s . v . geàrr a ’ chuain . ]
When you can ’ t take a handful from a crevice , you can take a fingerful .
[See Glossary s . v . cnagan]

In the twinkling of a pig ’ s eye ( al . a rat ’ s eye ) .
( Uist )
The piper ’ s forty days of hospitality .

The Mean Fellow ’ s hospitality : help yourself , help yourself , housewife , you ’ re not taking anything .
( Uist )
Big Norman ’ s hospitality : wait , wait , the hen ’ s in the creel , and my wife ’ s at the shore .

Sluggard ’ s age : eighty at low water , sixty at high water , and hardly twenty at full moon .
( Uist )

The heron has one chick and it is cross and churlish ; the wren has twelve and they are docile and good - tempered .
( Argyll )

Doubtful ’ s agreement with Untruthful .
( Uist )
[Cf . N 45 , 6 ; Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 21 , s . v . brionnag . ]
A new apron in front of Neil !

[C . comments that this is “ an echo of the MacLean incident at Inverkeithing ” . If so , the Neil referred to could be Niall Buidhe , a brother of Eachann Bacach an t - Aosdana , and one of the warriors who defended Sir Hector MacLean of Duart at the Battle of Inverkeithing in 1651 . See A . MacLean Sinclair ( ed . ) , The MacLean Bards , i , p . 28 and pp . 46 - 7 . ]

w.lemma: an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr
an uair ar ar n- àr

text.p: [Similar place - names ( Achadh Dubhaidh and Leunaidh ) are found in Glenurquhart , where a fragment of this version was recorded . See TGSI , xlv , p . 390 . ]
A change of weather occurs at the time of the Budger ’ s Moon .
[See J . Gregorson Campbell , Witchcraft and Second Sight , pp . 306 - 7 . Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 22 , s . v . broc . ]
Ba ho , ba ho , ba ho , my child , your relatives are very plentiful down in the glens ; some are excellent pipers in Kintyre , while others are in Oban on an ale - house table .
[It is possible that those on the ale - house table were being eaten ! See “ The Second Shepherd ’ s Play ” in A . C . Cawley ( ed . ) , The Wakefield Pageants , pp . 56 - 8 . for the same motif . ]

The village where daylight comes late .
( Uist )
[This tradition is known in other parts of the Highlands , e . g . Tiree , where it was a common prank to fill windows with turf during the night . ]
Having milk in winter is like getting honey from the ground .

I would prefer a “ wooden minister ” to a hound of a minister .
( Uist )

[C . betrays his own denominational stance in his note ! The term “ ministear - maide ” was ( and still is ) usually applied derisively to a non - evangelical , “ worldly ” minister , irrespective of denomination . ]

Advance , by the point or the edge of the sword !
( Argyll )
[The significance of the original saying is not entirely clear . It could also mean “ Advance , whether you face the point or the edge of the sword ” . ]
A golden crop surrounds the Isle of Ulva .
[See P . A . MacNab , “ The Golden Fringe ” , The Scots Magazine , 93 , No . 6 ( September , 1970 ) . ]
A walking stick in a boot .
[ ? i . e . , a hindrance . ]

That would be like going to the gallows after a fever .
( Uist )
That would be like sending horses to the Hebrides .
[A Gaelic equivalent of “ Carrying coals to Newcastle ” . Cf . N 50 , l , 2 , 3 . ]
Whether a Carmichael be big or small , you can face death with him .
A woman with only one son has no son at all .

A woman until old age and a man until death .
( Uist )

[C . translates “ gu aois ” as “ to her term of life ” , and explains that the woman and the man “ can bear or beget children to these stages respectively ” . Cf . N 183 , l ; and also RC2 , p . 481 , “ Bean gus an téid i eug is fear gus am bi e ’ na sheann reud ” ( “ A woman until she dies and a man until he is old and decrepit ” ) , which has the note , “ They will be learning until then ” . ]

A woman with calm eyes .
( Argyll )
The cat ’ s compliments to the mouse .

Farewell to what has gone ; it will not suffice .
( Perthshire )

Bless the table and fill the stomach . Thou who didst send us this meal , may thou send us another , from meal to meal , until the final meal . Thou who didst create the world , keep people from evil . May he who wishes us harm fare badly himself .
( Skye )

The whelk will sustain a person until it makes him as black as its own shield .
( Uist )
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 70 , s . v . faochag . ]
Benbecula , the biggest ben in the world .
Patience can overtake the day that has not come ( i . e . , the future ) , but it cannot overtake the day that will not come ( i . e . , the past ) .
A tailor ’ s wealth consists of two farthings and a thimble .
A sweet mouth and a heart of holly .
[C . attributes this saying to a N . Uist teacher who died some twenty years before he recorded it . ]
It would be better to have a foray in the land than a fine St Bridget ’ s Day .

I ’ d rather go to exhume a dead body .
( Uist )
[It could mean simply that exhuming a body is a very unpleasant task . ]
The cattle ’ s presence is better than “ Ho ! Ho ! ”

I had hoped to go to Edinburgh , but I ’ ll go to Barra instead .
( Uist )
It was in the Providence - plan that he should do this .
[See Glossary s . v . tairgneachd . ]

I ’ ve been to a tinker ’ s wedding before now .
( Argyll )

[i . e . , I know how to handle a difficult situation . C . says that the saying is “ a polite way to stop intimidation ” . For a description of a tinker ’ s wedding , see H . Whyte , Leabhar na Céilidh , pp . 30 - 3 . ]
The fairy woman has touched him .
[C . passed on the word “ gonadair ” in this sense to Dw . , who defines it as “ Man with an evil eye , one who can bewitch — Argyllsh . ” ]

Her Hogmanay will cripple her .
( Uist )

The deer takes salt from the hill , but fish do not take salt from the sea .
( Argyll )
Harvest will bear itself out .

The sea will claim its own .
( Uist )
[See W . J . Watson ( ed . ) , Rosg Gaidhlig , pp . 14 f . ]
Shaking brings butter from cream .
He will give away his mother ’ s milk from his nose .

Flies dancing in winter will bring sorrow to the farmer .
( Argyll )
[See Glossary s . v . gnàithseach . ]
Food and clothes .
Let every cow have its own calf .
[Cf . W . Douglas Simpson , The Historical St Columba , pp . 5 f . ]
Let your mouth be like the mouth of the mussel .

Have your distaff ready ; God will send the tow .
( Argyll )
Let that be as seems suited to it .
The Scoor will remain there and I will remain here .
The friend of the lady of the house will be in the upper part of the house .

Even a silly little boy will remember that May Day fell on a Friday .
( Argyll )
[Cf . N 267 , 10 , which makes May Day unlucky if it falls on a Thursday ; J . Gregorson Campbell , Witchcraft and Second Sight , p . 297 ; Fr . Allan , p . 39 , sv . Bealltuinn . ]

The day will have a dirty ending .
( W . Isles )
[For other stories about Gilleasbuig Aotrom , see N . MacLeod , Clarsach an Doire , pp . 233 f . Cf . TGSI , xxx , p . 167 . ]

I ’ ll have a hog there in any case .
( Inverness district )
The friend of the lady of the house will get next to the fire .
The year of the great heat .
The year of the wild Martinmas .
[See J . Barron , The Northern Highlands in the Nineteenth Century , ii , p . 24 . ]

Years given on loan .
( Sutherland )

The yellow cows will be milked and their milk will be drunk , when the white cows return home unsold .
( Uist )
The frenzy of Christmas - time .
A kick on the bottom and a blow on the mouth .
A weaver , a tailor and a pig .
You have to break the bone while others take the marrow .

Thick , raw porridge for boys , and thin , cooked porridge for girls .
( Uist )
A welted shoe is praised , but nobody knows who will wear it .

The Lewisman ’ s way of cooking the bannock — sitting on it .
( Uist )

[Elsewhere , this delicacy was known as
“ Bonnach an Taibh ” ( “ The Ocean Bannock ” ) . ]
A seal pup would by nature go backwards to the shore .
She was a forward woman who first put a finger in your mouth .
[See Waifs and Strays , i , p . 50 ; B . K . Wilson , Scottish Folk - tales and Legends , pp . 38 f . The original significance of the saying is not clear . ]
Soldiering would be good were it not for the battles .
His journey was a happy one .
Said of the death of an infant . [See no . 665 . ]
The herd - boy who is dirty - footed at night did not , and will not , keep cattle .

Success to his hand !
( Uist )

Ring the little bells before you try the big one .
( Barra )

The ferment of the gruel pot will go no farther than the ashes .
( Perthshire )
The big yellow flower of Michaelmas .

A common name for the harvest moon .
[Cf . N 197 , 7 . ]
The blow of the king ’ s - hood on the stomach .
[Cf . N 377 , 5 . See Glossary s . v . broilean and maodal . ]
Irregular [oar - ] strokes are unsightly [oar - ] strokes .
[Sim . RC2 , p . 482 , with the note , “ in rowing ” ; cf . N 73 , 5 . ]
Mashed potatoes with milk is the food of the old men of the Aird .
[For information on the Aird district of Inverness - shire , see TGSI , xlv , pp . 196 f . ]
Sleep , O King ! The world will go round .

Relationship , obligation and acquaintance .
( Uist )

Where is a lame man to be found but among the lame ?
( Argyll )
May the whole year ’ s loss accompany it !
[C . notes this phrase along with no . 155 , and translates it “ Food and kitchen ” . See Glossary s . v . calp , innlinn and aindeal . ]

Much about the same , like Patrick and the cow .
( Argyll )

A fireside fight is a hot , tight battle .
( Argyll )

Send away the greedy , forward fellow with a morsel in his mouth .
( Perthshire )
A long , bent kiln - flue with its mouth towards the south .
[The flue with the best draft . Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 37 , s . v . cealach . ]
A Kintail sandwich — thick bread , thicker butter and cheese thicker than that .
A happy hen .
A tradesman without a trade is the worst possible tradesman .
Four attractive things , a lion , a deer - hound , a he - goat and an unconquerable king .
May the mist of Lanno and Lego come upon you !
In Fingalian myth [i . e . MacPherson ’ s compositions] , Lake Lanno in Scandinavia and Lake Lego in Ireland emitted noxious vapours from the infernal regions . See Temora , vii .
Mist during the waning of the moon will be followed by snowfall and snowdrift .
Be careful that good luck does not leave your house on the first Monday of the quarter .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , iv . p . 151 ; W . Matheson ( ed . ) . The Blind Harper , pp . 115 - 6 . ]
A step on the hack .

[i . e . , an unwilling step . C . gives
“ gearradh - feòirnein ” ( “ grass - blade cut ” ) as an equivalent of
“ gàg ” . ]
On Christmas Day , the day is longer by a cock ’ s stride .
[Cf . BP , no . 83 ; Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 48 , s . v . cois - cheum , coilich . )

The land - labourer ’ s step .
( Uist )
[See Glossary s . v . gnàithseach . ]
May the agony of the Cross be yours !
( Literally , “ May you be crucified ” . But cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 40 , s . v . ceus - chrann . See Glossary s . v . ceusda - chrann . ]

I was not brought up on frogs .
( Perthshire )

The seals did not learn their music on the rocks .
( Uist )
[See TGSI , xlv , p . 12 . ]
Windy - bottom did not have a holding long .

The raven ’ s share will not be drowned .
( Lochaber )

There is no one alive who can bring home all the fish in the sea .
( Uist )

There is nothing high or low which is not coveted by an Islay man ’ s eye ; there is nothing in a corner or a store which is not sought by a Mull man ’ s eye ; a Coll man will steal what a Mull man leaves behind ; pity the poor person who entrusts his goods to a
[Cf . N 110 , 5 ; The Active Gael , pp . 68 f . ]
Bread is remembered only as long as it stays in the gullet .

A timid person will not be brave .
( Uist )
Only a man without courage will be without a wife , and there will be no such man .
[The last part of the saying is deliberately ambiguous . ]
Only a foolish woman can boil an egg .

A one - legged hen will not gain much by scraping .
( Uist )

I would not like to fight with you ; your brow is close to your eye .
( Uist )
The crows will not devour you this year .

That ’ s no favour from you , as the pullet said to the sparrow - hawk ( al . to the hawk ) .
( Uist )
Old wives ’ good - will must be purchased .
It ’ s no steady relationship , but an unstable one .

You have never heard anything except the sound of a wave and the honk of a goose .
( Uist )
In the Sound of Odrum over yonder , where the seals would sleep , and where no human voice could be heard — only the sound of a wave and the honk of a goose .

Alasdair does not ascribe every good thing to the past ; every good thing lies in front of him .
( Perthshire )
[Presumably this is used of a person who is optimistic about the future . ]
Neither tax nor commerce burden the mind of a child .
[For more sayings attributed to MacCodrum , see W . Matheson ( ed . ) , The Songs of John MacCodrum , pp . 204 f . ]
He ’ ll not put off his plaid till he goes to bed .

A cuckoo will not become a priest .
( Barra )

Whistling will not gather manure ( al . , cut peat ) .
( Uist )
All the gold of Spain will not ennoble a covetous man .

Mist with the waning moon never left the new moon without rain .
( Inverness district )
You have never left the dung - hill pond .
No fisherman was ever satisfied with biting and nibbling .
I didn ’ t get enough to revive a cat in a faint .
[Presumably said of a bad day ’ s fishing . ]
The orphan who show hospitality to a stranger is no orphan .
A Sutherland man and a Reay man never agreed .
A grave never refused , however hard the frost .

You have not pulled his whisker .
( Uist )
No one was ever killed in the Almost Battle .
No one ever committed one murder without committing another .
No one ever sighed without a drop of blood falling down in his heart .

I didn ’ t look so low
( Uist )
Fault - finding never abrogated the law .
You have not turned over his rough side .
[i . e . you do not know the unpleasant side of his character . ]
You didn ’ t understand what it was like to go to reap in Monkstat .
[Monkstat is the name of a large holding in the Duntulm district of Skye . See A . Nicolson . Handbook to the Isle of Skye , pp . 25 - 6 . ]

No one ever understood the intention of a Skyeman ( al . No one ever found out . . . ) .
( Uist )

Only a complete fool ever said “ I don ’ t care ” .
( Argyll )
A tailor is not a man , and two tailors do not amount to a man ; a raven could throw two score and two of them over a cliff .
[Cf . W . Matheson ( ed ) , The Songs of John MacCodrum , p . 270 . ]
St Columba ’ s robe will not fit every man .

The Atlantic Ocean will not clean the red hand of the murderer .
( Uist )
The candle will not last when lit at both ends .

A house is none the worse for having a “ Moderate ” in it .
( Uist )

[C . notes that “ the term ‘ Moderate ’ was applied to one who did not secede from the Church of Scotland . ” But it originated much earlier than 1843 , and was usually applied to a non - Evangelical minister . See A . L . Drummond and J . Bulloch , The Scottish Church , 1688 - 1843 , pp . 64 f . ]

Soap would not wash her .
( Uist )

The manure will not pay for the grazing .
( Uist )
[i . e . , the manuring done by cattle while grazing . Cf . N 337 , 3 . ]

Marion cannot marry on her own .
( Uist )

He will not sell his potato - field sideways .
[i . e . , in such a way that the buyer can see the gaps in the rows . See Dw . s . v . dail - bhuntàta , where the saying is explained . ]

April was never without a white coat ( of snow ) .
( Perthshire )
[C . notes that the “ Giblin ” comprises the second half of April and the first half of May . ]
There was never a tinker of the MacLeod race .
There was never a gossiper who was reliable .

There was never a bad - tempered person who didn ’ t give trouble .
( Uist )

There weren ’ t twenty drunk men at your grandfather ’ s funeral .
( Skye )
The Devil ’ s servant was never idle .
Shrove - tide never occurred without a waxing moon nor Easter without a waning moon .

I was never in Button ’ s house .
( Uist )
There was never a reel in Borreray .
There was never a lazy person who wasn ’ t a thief .
There was never joy without sorrow ; there was never a December without cloud ; young people were never
[Cf . N 126 , 3 ; Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 14 , s . v . beulaiche . ]
Nothing was heavy without being productive , except stones and dead men .
[ “ Trom ” can also mean “ pregnant ” . The pun is lost in translation . ]
A man on his own is not a multitude .

A cat never had offspring that did not mew .
( Uist )
The evil of a vicious attack is no small matter [ ? ]
[See Glossary s . v . teic . ]
The people of Torrin will not go to fish until the cats bring herring ashore .

Pride will not oppose profit .
( Uist )

This saying is used when a well - off person is found doing something which might be considered beneath him , but which is profitable to him .
[But cf . N 361 , 3 . ]

No one spits in his own blanket .
( Uist )
A blow with the fist is no return for a kiss .
He could not lift salt off the table .
No one gives a blessing without getting it back .
Neither bailiff nor minister can bring down what isn ’ t up .
Nothing can be got from gold but its usefulness .
Dwarf - corn never caused a famine in Uist .
[Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 76 , s . v . coilchean . ]

You did not reach St Kilda in an egg - shell .
( Argyll )
A Lewis woman will not understand that there is a foray until it reaches her door .
The matter became dough .
The skill surpassed MacCrimmon .
[See TGSI , xlv , p . 5 ; J . Mackenzie ( ed . ) Sar - Obair nam Bard Gaelach , pp . 104 f . ]

She lost her top grain
( Argyll )
No thaw lasts except one from the north and no snowfall lasts except one from the south . ( Uist )
It is not for nothing that Silly washes Sinister ’ s bottom .
Not everyone will get the Laird of Bernera ’ s daughter .

He is not your lover but the one you will not marry .
( Uist )
You haven ’ t got the blacksmith ’ s anvil under it .

It is not that good weather will not come , but that the bad man will not wait for it .
( Perthshire )
There are only three weeks between the good and the bad barber .

A fortunate man only to be born ; an unlucky man needs to be born and brought up .
( Uist )
The only remedy for hardship is to harden to it .
The only remedy for dire poverty is hard work .
The red - hot hook is not out of you yet .
There is nothing in Lochmaddy but English and hunger .
There ’ s nothing for it but Donald for himself .

There is nothing worse then corn refuse .
[Cf . N 112 , 9 . ]
A scoundrel has no ear for music .

The food is not stand - offish , unless the people are .
( Argyll )

You have no favour to claim from me ; I don ’ t like you .
( Benderloch )
There is no lament like the lament of poverty .

Poverty cannot be changed for the better .
( Uist )
The Campbells ’ roof - turf is not waterproof .

[There is a pun on “ dìon ” , which can also mean “ protection ” . The saying can equally well be translated : “ The Campbells ’ roof - turf will not keep you safe ” , i . e . , they are not to be trusted]
He ’ s not as deadly as his threats suggest .

No one knows what would be good for a scabby head .
( Uist )

[A Tiree variant adds
“ — fuachd no teas ” ( “ cold or heat ” ) .
There is no one without a “ were it not ” .
There isn ’ t a string in my harp .

He hasn ’ t got enough sense to drive the cat from the cream .
( Stratherrick )
The like has not been seen since the ram gave birth to the lamb in Scalpay .

A good pair of tongs was never seen in the blacksmith ’ s house .
( Uist )
[Cf . BP , no . 64 . ]
A man on horseback fleeing for his life could not see it .

He is never seen drunk and he is never seen well - clad .
( Uist )
You will not die from emaciation this year .
Neither sea nor land will hide injustice ( al . guilt ) .
The East lad is no better than the West lad — they are both drab and speckled .
It is not worth while making it last two Martinmasses .
Truth spoken in anger is not truth .
Neither shaking not stroking would satisfy her .

Killing a grouse is not the same thing as bowing to it .
( Uist )

Even the fox itself cannot always keep running .
( Kintyre )
I see , I see on the far horizon , over the russet bog - myrtle , a son being born of a mother , and a mother being born of him .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 276 , s . v . fà . ]

That will be seen in the cat ’ s face .
( Uist )
As thievish as a rat .
As melodious as a fairy bell .
[See Glossary s . v . clag - sith . ]

As clumsy as the fly which went into John MacCodrum ’ s milk .
( N . Uist )
[Cf . Dw . s . v . cearbach . ]
As musical as the cow which ate the piper .

[This motif is international . See Stith Thompson , Motif - index of Folk Literature , iv , p . 161 , J 1815 , Getting Rid of Man - eating Calf . A version in which a piper fleeing home after Culloden is supposedly eaten by a cow has been recorded several times in Gaelic Scotland . For a summary of the salient features of the Irish versions , see O Suilleabhain and Christiansen , The Types of the Irish Folktale , pp . 228 - 9 . ]
As stand - offish as the ravens of Heisker .
As good - hearted as a gull .
As dark as the brown cow ’ s stomach .
As black as a stick for parching grain .
[See Glossary s . v . maide - gradanaidh . ]
As black as night .
As familiar with sparks as the smith ’ s dog .

As familiar ( with something ) as a minister ’ s goat is with music ( al . singing ) .
( Argyll )

A long as water flows at Strome , there will be a twist in the Lochcarron man .
[See no . 58 . ]
As delicately careful as a cat ( walking ) on snow .

[C . seems to take “ faoilidh ” as a variant of “ fàilidh ” ( “ gentle , careful ” ) , but Mr Kenneth MacDonald informs me that in Wester Ross “ faoilidh ” means “ exposed , wind - swept ” , and that this may well be its meaning here . ]
As watchful as a curlew ’ s eye .

As white as a wax candle .
( Uist )

As sharp as MacEachern ’ s awl — it went through six folds of shoe - leather and half a finger - length into the king ’ s bottom .
( Argyll )
As clean as a covering - skin .
[See TGSI , xlv , p . 7 ; Glossary s . v . iomaideal . ]

As pure as sunlight .
( Uist )

As silly as the Virgin ’ s crosses .
( Uist ) .
[See Glossary s . v . Croisean - Moire . ]
As swift as a May squirrel .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . feòrag . ]

A backside ( fed ) in two houses is as fat as a seal .
( Uist )
As conceited as a two - year - old cat .
As conceited as the only gull by the side of the Sound of Mull .
An allusion to the scarcity of shellfish etc . on the Sound of Mull . The usual food of seagulls is so scarce that only one can survive , [and it has consequently little of which to be proud . ]
As swift as the storm - riders .
[Cf . N 142 , 5 . See Glossary s . v . gathan - dubha . ]

As well off as a fattening cow .
( Uist )
As fond of it as a MacLeod is of a cat .

As ancient as the banner of the Abrach MacKays .
( Strathnaver )
[See M . O . MacDougall , The Clan MacKay , p . 8 . ]

As happy as a little trout in a stream .
( Skye )
As happy as a rat in a mill .

As mournful as the cry of the Atlantic .
( Uist )
As dry as kiln - straw .

As thick as peas in a poke .
[Sim . RC2 , p . 488 . ]
He turned up his white side .
He could fasten the twenty - four thongs to the fingered pack - saddle .
[Said of a very dexterous person . See Glossary s . v . srathair - mheurach . ]
He saw a heath - hen last night .
[Said of a person who looks pale and worried . The heath - hen was thought to be a bird of ill - omen . ( Dw . s . v . liath - chearc . ) ]
I saw what I lost and that doesn ’ t resemble it .
[Presumably said of a substantial loss . ]
I saw one who heard one who saw another who said that he saw one who saw the king .
The sense of a herdsman ’ s cow .
Kilmaree on the wing of the bay , cold Camusiunary among the hills , Robastan of the unripe corn — I would love to be there .
[See A . Nicolson , Handbook to the Isle of Skye , p . 67 . ]

What else do you want , cat , except meat ?
( Uist )

What is the greatest wonder of the world ? Wealth ; good and evil result from it .
( Uist )
What ruins landlords is a lack of farmers .
[There may be a pun on “ cion ” , which can mean “ poverty ” , so that the saying could be translated “ What ruins landlords is the poverty of farmers ” . ]

Gentle with the cow , stem with the horse .
( Uist )
Ruric ’ s memorial - stone .
[From loose sheets within covers of MS . No explanation is given . This may be a reference to a large

boulder on the shore - line just below Appin House . It is said to have been rolled down the hillside against a tone of marauding Norsemen , led by a man called Ruric , who was killed by it . See TGSI , xlviii , pp . 502 - 3 . ]

Like Lamont ’ s wife , I ’ d be as well without it .
( Easter Ross )

Like the sand - diggers , waiting until day .
( Uist )

Like the black - tailed crane , mocking every bird in the flock .
( Uist )
[See Glossary s . v . corrònta . ]
Like the lark , which ceases to sing when it reaches its nest .

Like the Benbecula people — the work we don ’ t do today , we ’ ll do tomorrow .
( Uist )
The MacIntyres from the side of Cruachan who are brave by nature , though they lost the right which their kin had in Sleat .
[Cf . the concluding stanza of Ailean Dall MacDougall ’ s “ Oran do Mhac ’ Ic Alasdair Ghlinne - Garaidh in John Mackenzie ( ed . ) , Sar - Obair nam Bard Gaelach , p . 327 . ]
The MacCallums — the descendants of the Sixty fools who spilled their blood at Achavean .
The dogs of the land will hear of it .
Knapdale , where they put sense into horses !
Whoever is to blame , I am the sufferer .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi . p . 52 , s . v . crionalach ; N 193 . 6 . ]
A March rooster is always a steady signaller .
The dogs of Barcaldine and the children of Ichrachan .
Dogs , boys and tinkers .
Like Uist cheese — it is rank , tough and hard .
It is often in pieces , like the door of the daughter of Donald , son of John .

Like the people of Paible , taking their bread from the gruel .
( Uist )
[The saying may also be translated , “ deriving my sustenance from gruel ” , and MacDonald possibly meant that as there was a shortage of meal , he was compelled to live on gruel . ]

God keep you , and may neither beast nor ghost harm you !
( Uist )

Lachlan ’ s chance to catch the ram .
( Uist )
The religion of the Glen — pig - dealing .
[Cf . TGSI , xlix , p . 247 . ]
A short , ramshackle plough , with uncontrollable horses pulling it , a senseless woman leading them , and the soil tough and shallow .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 79 , s . v . ganndach . ]
The dog wags its tail for the person who gives it something .
The religion of the yellow stick .

[i . e . , the Protestant religion . Dw . Notes , s . v . , that “ A Coll priest of former times was accustomed to drive recalcitrant natives to church by a smart application of his walking - stick . . . Another version says Hector , son of Donald MacLean of Coll , was

the one who applied the yellow stick . Hector was laird in 1715 , and as the religion of the yellow stick was introduced into Rhum in 1726 , It Is beyond doubt that Hector was the author or propagator of it . . . ” Dr Samuel Johnson noted ( Journey to the Western Isles of Scotland , p . 115 ) that he met the laird of Rhum who possessed the yellow stick , “ I suppose a cane for which the Earse had no name ” . ]

A heart without hope and a bow without an arrow resemble each other .
( Uist )

Death and marriage put an end to earning .
( Skye )

A Devil cutting a gibbet for himself .
( Uist )

Though the year be hard , the distiller will keep his bag .
( Stratherrick )
[Cf . BP , no . 196 . ]
The angry cat ’ s hoard — who can get it ?
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 255 , s . v . cugan . ]

Turn hardship into insignificance .
( Uist )

Send word by the black sticks .
( Inverness district )
i . e . , by telegraph . Applied sarcastically to a person who is slandering someone known to the hearer of the slander . [C ’ s explanation is not entirely convincing . ]

Frighten off the ghosts .
( Skye )
[Cf . DW . s . v . loguid ; Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 100 , s . v . logaid . ]

Pass it on .
( Argyll and Uist )
[For the Argyllshire tradition regarding its origin , see TGSI , xlv , p . 10 . ]
Let me pass on Struileag .
[See Glossary s . v . Struileag . ]
Doctor avoids medicine for himself .

Keep going , your bread is baked .
( Skye )
Let him carry on until his nose advises him . [i . e . , until he is struck on the nose . ]

Snowfall and drifting , snow and frost , wait until St Fillan ’ s Day .
( Perthshire )
Two things very difficult to choose , a wife and a sword .
Two lights tonight and a wisp tomorrow night .

Make a sheep of yourself and the hounds will eat you .
( Skye )

Treat it as a spell or as a charm , the matter is just like that .
( Benderloch )
When in Oban , do as the people of Oban do .
The end of the Devil is hanging .
The Stirrup - cup ! The happy drink ! The drink which assures us of a successful journey ! The health of the clan from which we sprang ! Here it is ! There it is ! Let ’ s know you ’ ve taken it .
I knew by your eyes that you came from Uig .
Mo ghaol air do shùil ged bhiodh do bhrù aig na coin .

Lachlan left his croft ; no , it was his croft that left Lachlan .
( Argyll )
You ’ ve perished , Ardnaclach !

He drank the milk of the foolish cow which ate the bog - violet .
( Uist )
[See TGSI , xlv , p . 13 . Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 184 , and Carm . Gad . , vi , s . v . mòthan . See Glossary s . v . ]

Thursday is gentle St Columba ’ s Day ; the day to send sheep to pasture , the day to lay warp , and to give a calf a foster - mother .
( Uist )
[Cf . N 168 , 9 . St Columba ’ s Day is the Thursday of the second week of June . See F . Marian MacNeill , The Silver Bough , iii , pp . 83 - 5 . ]
Friday is best for growing , Tuesday is best for reaping ; but work begun on Monday will be either fast or slow .
[Cf . N 33 , 6 ; BP , no . 19 ; Carm . Gad . , p . 261 , s . v . Di . ]

On Mondays and Fridays hair will grow on a bald man .
( Skye )
[Presumably these were thought to be “ good growing days ” ! ]
I ploughed on a Tuesday , I sowed on a Tuesday , I reaped on a Tuesday ; O Thou who hast given me all three Tuesdays , preserve my appetite and my supply .
[Cf . Waifs and Strays , iii , p . 218 and p . 289 ; Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 76 , s . v . gàdag . ]

Money deserves to be counted twice .
( Uist )
Have your desire in spite of —

The thieving of Lismore folk .
( Argyll )
[From loose sheets within covers of main MS . See TGSI , xlv , p . 14 ; Glossary s . v . dòmanachd . ]

A dog ’ s dram — a crack on the nose .
( Benbecula )

Shut the west window , once it begins to get dark .
( Uist )

[A saying attributed to
“ Niall Coingeasach ” ( “ Indifferent Neil ” ) . The west window was shut to prevent fairies or evil of any kind from entering the dwelling by night . See TGSI , xlv , pp . 15 - 18 . ]

A dark - haired man is bold ; a fair - haired man is soft ; a brown - haired man is conservative ; a red - haired man is stubborn .
( Uist )
A man without a horse or a boat carries his burden far behind .
A man who does neither good nor harm does more harm than good .
A two - faced man is better with you than with me .

Dun Bhuirg is on fire !
( Uist )

[See TGSI , xlv , p . 18 . Tiree tradition states that the fairies once invaded the island from Mull where they had their fortress , Dùn Bhuirg . When the above cry was raised , they returned to Mull as quickly as possible . Cf . Waifs and Strays , i , pp . 54 - 5 and p . 62 . ]
Between the door - post and the door .
Between Kintail and the wall of France .

Between two May Days .
( Uist )
Between floating and sinking , like James and his blanket .
Between Ness and the Nunnery in Uig .
Quick to promise , quick to forget .

You eel , you nit , you frog ! Get out of my way !
( Lismore )
A boat made of the ends of planks , and a creel made of the ends of rods .
A new boat and old rocks .

An ameliorative [expiatory ( ? ) ] ransom .
( Benderloch )

[Heard from an old man who was speaking of Barcaldine Castle and said that a man had been buried alive under its foundation as an “ éirig mheachainn ” — a kind of scape - goat . See TGSI , xlv , p . 18 . ]
St Columba ’ s charm for the old woman ’ s one cow .
[These are the opening lines of a charm . See The Highland Monthly , iv . pp . 436 - 7 . Cf . no . 644 . ]
The knowledge of the dark eye .
A word from the mouth and a bird on the wing .
The length of its leg for a calf ; the length of its side for a puppy ; the length of its jaw for a kid , firmly fastened to the tetherpin .
[Cf . N 174 , 1 ; Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 120 , S . V . roith . ]
Let your burden rest on your securities .
Take care of your toll , miller .
[See TGSI , xlv , p . 19 . Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 55 , s . v . cùileag . ]
A welcome turned cold .
A ring on her finger and rags on her bottom .
A lover feels the arrow in his sleep , but a lazy man doesn ’ t feel an arrow in his side .

Waulking will hide the faults .
( Uist )
Language may be polite even though it is bitter .
He may become a good man yet , but he hasn ’ t got a good man ’ s face .
He can stand on a high hill .
456 . Faodaidh luchd nam falluinnean dearga [a bhith] gun an calg a bhith fuilteach .
Those that had red robes ( i . e . , deer ) need not have blood - stained hair .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 273 , s . v . , falluinn . ]
The seagulls of our own shore .
Where there is one attraction , there are many .
Where there is music , there is no unpleasantness .
The lamb will return to the place where it got milk .
Where fire is dispersed , there is cold ; where it is gathered together , there is heat .
Life , indigenous growth and fruit .
Barley seed will grow on a shore full of docken .
The flaying of the Rona bag .
[Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 36 , s . v . balg . ]

A late visit from a poor man is embarrasing .
( Uist )
Meat for your bread , like Cumming ’ s head .

[Used when a person contemplates revenge . It refers to the head of the son of Cumming of Raitts in Morayshire , which was brought to his father after he had been killed in a cave as retribution for a clan battle . See TGSI , xlv , p . 20 . ]

The fox ’ s servant has to lift its tail .
( Perthshire )
As long as a black cow gives ( white ) milk , as long as MacQueen ’ s Crogaire stays on its foundation , and as long as nails are found on hand or foot .

Thou who didst send rain - drops , send a real downpour .
( Perthshire )
The roadway invitation — any amount of “ How are you today ? ” and “ How are your people ? ”
A fiddler , a tailor and a cat ; a weaver , a shoemaker and a pig .
A weaver , a dyer and a badger .

Wine , prize and meat
( Uist )
[Sim . Dw . s . v . fochlas . ]
The big peat of St Finnan ’ s Eve .

The brothers ’ harvest .
( Argyll )

[The name for the period of fine weather during the months of October and November . It is given different names throughout the Highlands , but these usually refer to districts or to people who are late with their harvest work . See TGSI , xlv , p . 20 . ]

The sound of the knife without its cutting edge .
( Uist )
Cool off in the skin in which you warmed up .
Bloodshed results from a battle and a battle from a bullet .

The blood of the Stewarts flows in kings and tinkers .
( Arygll )

Hold on ! Wait for the cuckoo !
( Argyll )
Catch the fish while it swims .

Go your twenty - four ways .
( Uist )
[i . e . , get lost . ]
Go to MacSiridh ’ s house .
[i . e . , get lost . See Glossary s . v . MacSìrith . ]

Take it or leave it .
( Inverness district )
[Sim . Dw . s . v . guaid . ]
Gloomy Gaick of the crooked crevices .
[See TGSI , xlix , pp . 70 f . ]
Each one , and all together , against the world .
Every trick works till the trick of death .
[i . e . , death cannot be outwitted . ]
Let every business be done by agreement .
Keep every contemptible thing to the last .
[See Glossary s . v . diùbhras . ]
Every lamb is whiter than its mother , and its mother is as white as snow .

A laugh which ends in weeping .
( Uist )
The disease which afflicted the cow in Port Askaig — cold and hunger together .
Wind off the waves , wind through a hole , and keen wind of thaw .
Wind from beneath a sail , wind through a cranny , and wind from behind a door .

[The last line should perhaps be altered to
“ Is gaoth troimh chòmhl ’ an doruis ” ( “ And wind through the door - valve ” ) . ]
Cf . also
Wind through a hole , wind off the waves while the ship is under sail , and the cold wind of thaw .
The wind at Hogmanay will be the wind for the rest of the year .
[Cf . RC2 , p . 49l ; Fr . Allan , p . 135 , s . v . gaoth . ]

An east wind for the men of the sea !
( Uist )

[C . comments that the saying may refer to Scandinavians , presumably Norsemen , but this is not convincing . It may refer to the long spells of east winds experienced in the islands in winter time . Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 135 . s . v . gaoth . ]

A north wind at nighfall never lasted long .
( Uist )

A north wind and plenty of it !
( Uist )

Whoever finds the tongs will marry soonest .
( Uist )
Wherever you are by day , be in the Horse - Shoe ( anchorage ) by night .
Though the cuckoo is sweet , I do not think a tittle - tattle is sweet .
[See Glossary s . v . cuthag - chluaise . ]
Though wool is good , it can ’ t be eaten .
Though daylight is good , night is more kindly .
[For traditions connected with the MacFarlanes of Arrocher , see J . Mackechnie ( ed . ) , The Dewar Manuscripts Volume 1 , pp . 120 - 1 . Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 24 , s . v . buad] .

The lazy servant ’ s complaint about the Spring day — though one end of it is wet , the other end is dry .
( Uist )

[C . attributes this saying and its variant , no . 826 , to a Uist man , Donald Munro from Lochmaddy , who was well known for his laziness , and who was nicknamed “ An Speireag ” ( “ The Sparrow - hawk ” ) in derision . ]
The divination of New Year ’ s Eve .

Though I cannot go by the shore , I can go the long way round .
( Uist )

Though the shore is similar , the shellfish are different .
( Uist )
This means that newcomers differ from those who preceded them , although they may be in similar capacities .
[Cf . Fr . Allan . p . 71 , s . v . cladach ; J . L . Campbell , Seanfhocail agus Comhadan , p . 3 . ]
Although religion is good , enough of it is enough .
Though Creag - a ’ - Choth is big , it is of little use .

The reply of a Mull man when he was complimented on the size of his wife .
[Sim . RC2 , p . 492 . ]

Though a mourner will not die , he will decline .
( Uist )

Though you are grateful , do not break your dish .
[Cf . LP , no . 72 . ]

Even if the moon were to go eastwards ( al . the sun anti - clockwise ) , yesterday would not meet today .
( Argyll )
Though Argyll and the King should come , they couldn ’ t do it .
He took heart on loan .
[But Dw . , who quotes a variant s . v . iasad , states that this is “ an exaggerated way of saying that one would borrow anything ” . ]
I have eaten hot kale before now .
Good promised to come .
A cow will be milked ; a world will be peopled .
A person will recover from poverty [or illness] , but he will not recover from covetousness .
A drab little wife is found at the door of her own house , but a fine big wife goes from one man to another .

He could steal the eye from the heron .
( Uist )
A lobster , a mackerel and a seal are the three heroes of the sea .
Slanderous , back - biting , clip - tongued , chattering , thieving , lying .
They can carry a tale when they cannot carry a burden .
Catch the salmon as it leaps .
Spare your bashfulness .
[Or “ Keep your sense of shame ” . ]
The lazy lad ’ s burden at harvest time — he goes a long way with it , and he takes a long time about it .

A woman ’ s red hair and a man ’ s grey beard bring fortune and good luck to the slut who finds them in a stone - chat ’ s nest .
( Uist )
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 319 , s . v . rath . ]

527 . Gu fhine fhéin gach treun !
Let every hero go to his own clan !
A pimple on a buttock .
Tears and laughter are man ’ s best means of expression .

May the generous hand ever be full !
( Argyll )

May God keep His mothers and the hand that milks !
( Perthshire )
[Cf . Dw . s . v . màg . where a variant of this saying is given with “ muirichinn ” , “ children , family ” , or “ màthraichean ” above . ]
The young gull has the old gull ’ s voice .
[i . e . , it ’ s pretending to be older than it is . Cf . N 208 , 7 : RC2 , p . 493 ; Fr . Allan . p . 211 , s . v . sgàireag . ]
Hey ! Big Fellow of Succoth , were you ever in Gigha ? Yes . Does the smithy stand near the public - house ?
A catch question . Formerly , the clachan consisted of a place where the parish church , the local smithy and the public - house stood near each other . [Gigha is an island . ]

Ho ! Ho ! I ’ ve cheated you this time !
( Uist )
John of the Gaelic .

[From loose sheets within covers of MS . No explanation is given . The reference may be to John Cumming , a “ character ” from the Duthil district , who once caused consternation in an Elgin court by taking the oath in Gaelic , and by giving flippant answers to the Sheriff ’ s questions . See The Highlander , 30 Sept . 1876 . ]

Conceited flitting .
( Inverness - shire and W . Isles )

Applied when conceit makes a person change his house or occupation merely to impress others .
[Cf . GP , p . 54 , no . 12 . ]

Tell the truth and you may leave the country .
( Uist )
A change of work is a rest .
The strength of the back depended on that joint .
The sea is at the will of the wind .

You can tell a gentleman by his finger - nails .
( Uist )
[C . comments that this refers to bodies washed ashore on the Long Island , but its application is probably more general . Cf . Dw . s . v . ionga . ]

The best steersman is ashore .
( Lismore )
What ’ s at the mouth of the sack should be used sparingly ; what ’ s at the bottom will spare itself .
You have in you what was in the swine .
[Sim . RC2 , p . 494 . Possibly a reference to the swine of the Gadarenes in St Luke , 8 . ]
A cow and a woman give milk from the head .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . bleagh ; N 153 , 4 ; BP , no . 138 . ]
The smith ’ s dog flees under the anvil .

Sleep and death come from God , and I would not shut my eyes except in the name of Him who opened them .
( Uist )

I lost a bundle and not a wisp through burning .
( Uist )
It ’ s a small boat - song which two will not hear .

The least thing will make a scabby head bleed .
( Uist )
[Presumably said of a person with a cantankerous nature Cf . no 310] .
A thing has to be very insignificant for a woman not to taste it ; she will put her tongue on alum .
Even the shortest rest will delay a journey .
[Sim . RC2 , p . 494 . See Glossary s . v . uidhe . ]
Even a small house can accommodate friends .

A lark at daybreak sounds sweet , but a cockerel around midnight sounds sweeter .
( Uist )

Fear - coimhid na h - ùrnuigh — the regulator of prayer .
Fear - dìon nam baoth — the protector of the simple - minded .
Fear - dùsgaidh nan creidmheach — the waker of the faithful .
Fear - dùsgaidh nan naomh — the waker of the pious .
Fear - faire — the watchman .
Fear - faire na h - oidhche — the watchman of the night .
Fear - faire nan tràth — the watchman of the hours .
Fear - seannsaidh na maidne — the announcer of morning .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , iv , pp . 6 f . ; Fr . Allan , p . 77 , s . v . coileach . ]
Christmas without snow is poor fare .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . blianach . ]
Everyone he meets brings him misfortune .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 47 , s . v . còmhlaiche . ]

It is as good to go to the well with a creel .
( Argyll )
A sheaf of it is as good as a stook .
An old man thinks that the New Year is unkind .
Advice to one ’ s advantage ( al . the advice of older people ) ought to be accepted .
The Faoilteach ought to be given its three furrows .

[C . defines the Faoilteach as the second half of February and the first half of March , but the period seems to have varied from area to area . Cf . Dw . s . v . Faoilleach and Faoilteach . Dw . , s . v . Faoilteach , gives a variant of this saying , and explains that stormy weather towards the end of January indicated that a fruitful season would follow . ]
Hose is just like Stocking .
I don ’ t care for a person who sits in houses ; there was never a gossip who didn ’ t talk ; there was never a talker who didn ’ t tell lies ; there was never a liar who didn ’ t steal .
A man and his nature are close companions .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . companach . ]
Hunting is precarious , fishing is unreliable ; put your trust in the land — it never left a man empty .
[Cf . N . 158 , 1 ; Dw . and Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 255 , s . v . cugallach . ]
A wise man gleans at every time and place .
Pride must suffer pain .

The elbow is nearer than the fist .
( Uist )
A mother ’ s spirit is always near her orphaned child .
It is bad to be a tenant , but the very worst thing is to be a sub - tenant .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 239 , s . v . caithris . ]
It is difficult to make a man lucky against his will .

Dust was in the sack which was in the mill .
( Perthshire )

A charm against fairies . The first part is ambiguous , and can be taken as
“ ’ S tus ’ ” ,
giving “ You were… ” .
Its smallness is really its smallness now .

A sunny summer produces an excellent harvest .
( Uist )
The tailor makes the man .
[Doubtless sarcastic , as tailors were despised for their physical impediments . Cf . no . 249 . ]

The bare bird hops farthest .
( Pertshire )
The strength of the rope lies in the third strand .
Careful attention in youth builds the man .
[See Glossary s . v . anacladh . ]

Excess sail sinks narrow - beamed ships .
( Uist )
It is the fate of Highlanders to have nothing .

Your kind is easiest to find .
[Cf . no . 606 . ]

A bad day ’ s rowing makes the day good for rowing .
( Uist )

[Sim . Dw . , s . v . iomradh . But “ iomradh ” can also mean “ metion , report ” , so that the saying could be translated “ Mention of a bad day makes the day good for rowing ” , i . e . , the rowing will be all the better to avoid bad weather . ]

The cure for a cold is to eat something .
( Argyll )
What spoils poor people is their poverty
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 230 . ]
What wearies a worker is being idle .
The spoon has been taken out of his kale .
The lowing of a cow on the large meadow of Lassintulloch can be heard far away . ( Rannoch )
Misfortune has followed him for a long time .

The day is long for the person who has not removed the taste of night from his mouth .
( Uist )
The One to whom he is shouting is far from David Sutherland .
Diabaig is far from the law .

His left hand is longer than his right .
( Uist )
It is easier to sift him than to put him on horseback .

The bramble is better than the blackthorn ; the blackthorn is better than the Devil .
( Argyll )
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 265 , s . v . drìs . ]

The One who has ordained matters is better than the one who made the rebuke .
( Lochcarron )
The warmth of the fire is better than the taste of scarcity .
Hereditary is better than everthing else .
[Presumably applied to hereditary rights etc . ]
I prefer ( to see ) froth on a mean mouth to anything on earth .
Uist whey is better than warm Glasgow milk .
It is better to put a morsel in a beast ’ s mouth than to quarrel with it .
It is better to rub against a misfortune than to be bound to an affliction .
The sun rises cold on an old man ’ s dream .
The house is cold if the house - wife isn ’ t in good humour .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . aoibh . ]
It is easy to provide music for someone who likes dancing .
The person who gets a horse before he gets sense has a short ride .

There ’ s many a grey plaid at the market .
( Uist )
[i . e . , there are many of your kind . Cf . no . 580 . ]

The world takes many a cold , wet turn , as the chicken said ( as it stood ) on the mill - wheel .
[Cf . N 257 , 9 . ]
Many a strange dog has barked hotly in Benderloch . ( Benderloch )
Religion has spoiled many a nice man .
Many a person envies me today who never gave the least help .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . aidhseachadh . ]
A willing pair can do many things .
The inveterate visitor and the sleepy - head miss many a valuable thing .
There are many snowfalls on Maoloar ; many streams flow down [Glen] Lonan ; there are many mist - caps on Tom - na - mòna ; there are many foolish women in Strontoileir .
[The places mentioned are outside Oban] .

It is a wonderful thing : to be .
( Argyll )
The man who is outside is most dear to me — O ’ Bìrinn who lives in Breugach ; I spent a night in his house , with plenty of food but few clothes .

[The reply of the Earl of Mar on being told that the man who had helped him after the first Battle of Inverlochy ( 1431 ) was at his door . See W . J . Watson ( ed . ) , Rosg Gàidhlig , pp . 99 - 102] .
Deer are an innocent theft .

The blacksmith is strong , he can split iron ; but death is stronger than the blacksmith .
( Uist )

A mouse is strong under a haystack .
[Sim . RC2 , p . 498 . ]
The house which cannot hold one more is contemptible .
The world comprehended by the eye is insignificant .
[i . e . , the visible world . C . takes it to apply to the part of the universe seen by man . ]
The traveller suffers many mishaps ; you are best to stay on land .
[i . e . , the traveller by sea . ]
An old man makes many excuses for not going home to the churchyard ; he will go there with half step , but he ’ ll not return with half a step .
A big - bellied cow meets with many obstacles .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . . tuilbheum . See also Glossary s . v . )
A borrowed horse and a whip are swift on the road .

Pity the person who would call a strange woman ’ s son his brother .
( Uist )

[C . states : “ An illegitimate son cannot be depended on to show real brotherly affection . ” But the saying probably means that it is undesirable to claim relationship with an illegitimate child . Cf . N 105 , 5 . ]
Pity the person who would sprinkle his salt over him .
Pity the person who would shake the home .
Pity the person who would eat the light .
[i . e . , who would spoil a universal privilege ( HN ) . ]

Pity the person who falls into bad company .
( Uist )
Pity the person whose source of provision is the sea ; a patch of land is better than an ocean of land .
[Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 90 , s . v . cuile . ]
It ’ s a good year that looks after itself .
The miller ’ s wife bakes well ; well she may , since her supply is good .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 57 , s . v . cuinnlein . ]
Rye bread and seal blubber are good food for gathering seaware .

Good husbandry is a good profession .
( Uist )
It is a good sign of summer weather when distant lights shine with a reddish gleam .
It ’ s a good ship which gains the harbour from which she sailed .
[Or , more generally , when a person returns to an old haunt . ]
Butter , cheese and potatoes are good sustenance ; they are almost better than the limpet itself .
Easter is good when kept on Easter night .

Your caressing is good , but keep at it .
( Mull )
The dregs of patience are worth having .
A man is small when faced with death .
The blood of an enemy is sweet , but the blood of a friend is sweeter .
An early marriage was often a poor marriage , and a late marriage was often a blind marriage .

The old woman ’ s one cow was often lucky .
[Cf . no . 443 . ]
A greedy dog has often been scalded .

Heredity has often left behind a bad disease .
( Uist )
Fear has often resulted in strife .

A township is the worse for a man who intends to leave .
( Perthshire )
[Sim . Dw . s . v . bara . ]
Early on a Monday is unlucky for going to reap the Maiden .
The “ Maighdean ” ( “ Maiden ” ) was the last handful of corn to be cut . It was preserved and given as a handsel to horses when ploughing began in the following Spring .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 261 , s . v . Di ; F . Marian MacNeill , The Silver Bough , ii , pp . 120 - 3 . ]
Unfortunate is the person who loses his friend because of the gloomy clouds of a Spring morning .
Cleanliness is of great value , as the slut said as wiped the pail with the cat ’ s tail .

[ “ mar a thuirt an té ”
( HN ) . ]

A word goes for much until a solemn oath is taken .
( Uist )
[But cf . N 281 , 10 . Cf . also Waifs and Strays , v , p . 9 and p . 117 . See Glossary s . v . lughadh . ]

Greedy takes a great fill of her own whey .
( Uist )
[Sim . RC2 , p . 500 . Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 181 , s . v . miùg . ]

The outbits are bigger than the main field .
( Uist )
[See Glossary s . v . farbhradh and gnàitheach . ]
Grace is greater at a distance .

Happy is the person who kills a thief .
( Uist )
The stomach is a bad mistress .

It ’ s a bad stomach which cannot warm a drink for itself .
( Uist )
It ’ s a bad sea which rises after a calm .

You acted badly in striking me , when you haven ’ t yet given me a morsel .
( Perthshire )
Tears are a bad club ; today is for pursuing the enemy and tomorrow is for lamentation .

A healthy man is a king .
( Uist )
I stayed too long — until the cats bit off my ears .
Happy is the person who stands on the Hill of Expectation .
Happy is he who passes on in youth .

Even a trifling mishap can kill a fly .
( Uist )
Fishing is uncertain ; hunting is risky ; but whoever cultivates the land was never left empty by it .
[Cf . N 288 , 4 ; Dw . s . v . taomboileach ; no . 565 . ]

Smooth hailstones cause a change in every kind of weather .
( Argyll )

I like the seal , but I do not like the seal ’ s tidings .
( Uist )
[Cf . BP , no . 231 . ]

I like ploughing , but I do not like haphazard digging .
( Perthshire )

[ “ treabhadh réidh ”
( HN ) . ]

Marion likes her own clan .
( Uist )
One inch of a boy is stronger than two inches of a girl .

The rent is all the heavier because of the food - rent .
( Argyll )
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 38 , s . v . cearc - fearainn . ]
You are the worst Mac ’ Ic Eóghainn who has come , and the best who will ever come .
You lack finger - nails , just as St Columba did .
On St Bridget ’ s Day , the servant will receive full wages .
St Patrick ’ s Day in Spring is the day of twenty - seven sights ; these will suffice for horse and man , and horse and man will suffice for them .
The blacksmith ’ s fatigue comes upon the herd .
By my life , ( you ’ ve been ) sired by the Baron ’ s dog !

[Opposite p . 145 of his interleaved copy of Sar - Obair nam Bard Gaelach , C . notes that the Skye bard was “ the bard of MacKinnon of Strath . ” For a note on “ Am Bàrd Dòmhnallach ” , see TGSI , xlviii , pp . 3 - 4 . ]
To every cow belongs its calf and to every book its booklet .
[See no . 156 . ]

Anxiety accompanies choice .
( Skye )
Your heart would melt looking at him .
[Said of a person in poor circumstances . ]
He let his oars go with the current .

A mouse could jump over him .
( Inverness district )
Porridge of coarse - ground meal and choice goat ’ s milk .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 79 , s . v . garbhan . ]
Lochmaddy really has hounds in it .

Dark Loch Foghal is the deepest loch in the world ; but dark , deep Loch Lee is seven times deeper than Loch Foghal .
( Uist )

[The mountain was once a volcano , and its crater forms the bed of the loch . See W . Matheson ( ed . ) , The Songs of John MacCodrum , p . 302 , 1 . 2546 , note . C . suggests that Loch Foghal may be Loch Foyle in Ireland . Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 299 , s . v . li . ]
Choose a wife and a filly by the head .
A shaggy filly and a ragged boy .

A penny ’ s worth for a shilling .
( Uist )

Lucky is the person who finds St John ’ s wort , without looking for it or asking for it ; let me pluck the leaves of happiness as the High King commanded ; where it is found , there is success and peace .

[Cf . N 302 , 3 ; Fr . Allan , p . 20 , s . v . Luibh Chaluim Chille ; D . J . MacLeod ( ed . ) , Martin Martin , A Description of the Western Isles of Scotland , p . 347 ; F . Marian MacNeill , The Silver Bough , i . pp . 82 - 3 ; The Highland Monthly , iv , pp . 234 - 7 . See Glossary s . v . Luibh Chaluim - Chille . ]

The corn - cockle which leaves no blemish in the flesh .
( Uist and Skye )

[Fearchar Lighiche was an early member of the Beaton medical family , who flourished in the fourteenth century ( W . Nicolaiscn ( ed . ) , Proceedings of the The International Congress of Celtic Studies . p . 61 ) . For other sayings attributed to him , see J . F . Campbell , Popular Tales , ii . pp . 361 f . See Glossary s . v . Lus Charoline . ]
If you cheat your land , your land will cheat you .
If Sinister marries Crooked , how can the chick be anything but sinister and crooked .
[ “ Ma shuaineas Ciotach ri Crotaig ” ( HN ) . ]
She may be small , but she ’ s not soft .
If you are thirsty , God gave you the stream .
The MacNabs are the breed with big mouths , long ears and deer ’ s skulls .
Argyll and the King .
[See no . 512 . ]
MacMillans , Hendersons and MacNaughtons are to be found on the same hillock .
MacFadyen of the hen — although he waited to roast it , he didn ’ t wait to eat it .
[For a variant of this saying , “ current in Mull , in Islay and in Tiree , and probably elsewhere ” , see SGS , i ( 1926 ) , p . 80 . Cf . ibid . , p . 212 . ]
Pity the person who saw the little wild thyme on a bank , and did not pluck it .
[Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 171 , s . v . Lus Mhic Righ Bhreatainn . ]

Out and home again .
( Argyll )
[Used when a person makes a short trip from home . ]

O Mary , churn the milk - churn in the bottom of the glen ; may its milk curdle and its butter increase .
( Uist )
May you have a good fold of sons and quay calves !

[A Ross - shire variant has
“ Buaidh mhac is laoigh bhoireann ort ” .
See The Highlander , 24th June 1876 . ]

A bailiff , a priest and a hound .
( S . Uist )
The tree will lean in the direction that the twig is bent .
Like the cooper ’ s dog — what he cannot drink , he sits beside .

As Myles did , we ’ ll leave that at the disposal of Providence .
( Lismore )
[ “ Maol - Moire ” means literally “ the Devotee of Mary ” . ]

The carrying strap is apt to break when it ’ s tightest .
( Uist )

An evanescent autumn evening is like a stone rolling down a glen ; and a tenacious spring evening is like a lean cow coming home .
( Uist )

Like grease and barley bread .
( Stratherrick )
The names of the MacLeans sound like a dog drinking broth — Hector , Lachlan , Hector , Lachlan .
[Cf . RC2 , p . 502 ; The Active Gael , p . 86 . ]
You kill a cow and I ’ ll kill a parasite .
If Tonlee is bad , Turrag is no better .

If it is pounded grain ( al . Whether it is pounded or parched grain ) , give me a handful .
( Uist )

[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 65 , s . v . ealachadh .
See Glossary s . v . ealachadh and gradan . ]
If it is your kiln , extinguish it ; I ’ ll extinguish it if it is mine .
[i . e . , mind your own business . See TGSI , xlv , p . 21 . ]
If you think it ’ s a wild duck , I think it ’ s a swan .
If the world is yours , the people of the world are yours too .
[Cf . BP , no . 204 . ]
If the report is great , it is not a good one .
[i . e . , it is not to be trusted . See Glossary s . v . teisd . ]
Kindness to an insignificant man , kindness to an old man , kindness to a little child — three kindnesses which were never wasted .
[But cf . N 313 , 8 , which states the opposite ; cf . also MFS , p . 33 . ]

The mother of the man of the house is the Devil on floor .
( Tiree )
[Does this mean that she rules the roost ? ]
He can entice potatoes from a pot .
A thief who steals salt , and a thief who steals seed , and a thief who steals blue - grey lint ; though every thief should be pardoned , the thief who steals blue - grey lint shall not .
[See TGSI . xlv , p . 22 . Cf . N 391 , 4 ; MFS , p . 44 ; Carm . Gad . , ii , P299 , SN . lìon . ]
A fool would be considered wise if he knew how to keep quiet often .

The Kilpheder wife desires seal flesh .
( Uist )
Honey going into the Devil ’ s mouth .

An oath which ought not to be made ought not to be kept .
( Uist )
The oaths of the fox to the Grey Goat .
[i . e . , false oaths . See J . F . Campbell , Popular Tales , iii , pp . 91 - 3 and p . 102 ; Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 242 , s . v . ceabhar . ]
Donald of Coor ’ s oaths while standing on Callart soil .

[Used of a person who , when asked for a loan , says that he has nothing , even although he has money in his pocket . The saying originated when a farmer , “ Dòmhnall Mór na Cùir ” ( “ Big Donald of Coor ” ) , was arbiter in a land dispute . Standing on the disputed property , he swore that he was on Callart soil , Callart

being one of the townships claiming the land and the one to which he himself belonged . This was true , in so far as he had put some Callart soil in his boots before leaving home ! See TGSI , xlv , pp . 23 - 4 . ]

A fat bit in the middle of lean meat .
( Uist )

My association with John is the association of two silly folk ; what is mine is John ’ s , what is John ’ s is his own .
( Uist )

I much prefer your glug - glug to the minister ’ s clack - clack .
( Islay )

The conceit of Benbecula people .
( Uist )
The raven ’ s commendation of the bone — to strip it .

There ’ s murder in Carinish !
[See no . 793 . ]
Opposite each other , like Duart and Dunollie .
A pig , a dog and a sailor . ( Mull )
A Mull man , an Islay man and a devil .
If the day does not suit corn - cutting , it will do for munching nuts .
If you don ’ t like me , leave my kingdom !
Do not speak your finest word until the night before your death .
Do not ascribe a cow to a herd ; it will be taken from him at evening .
[Cf . N 49 , 1 ; Fr . Allan , p . 23 , s . v . ainmeachas . ]
Do not touch the eggs of a brooding bird ; the brood belongs to God .
Do not make a fuss about a tailor ’ s needle .
Do not go to the shore during high water when you have shellfish at home .
Do not take gulps when the liquid is thin .
The three most contemptible things that exist : pride without means , a pudding without fat , and a kiss from a mean mouth .
The three kindest things I ever met — my mother , my home and my purse .
You swallowed a large amount of butter on the calm night you were born ! Can ’ t you keep the cluck to yourself ?

A saying about the people of Eigg , whose speech is distinguished by a catch in the voice . [This is known as “ glug Eigeach ”
. Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 84 , s . v . glug . ]
The modesty of dogs during Lent .
If the serpent had its own head , it would destroy the world .
The reference would seem to be to the bruising of the serpent ’ s head in the Bible [Genesis 3 : 15] .
If the good things of the past were remembered , the good things of the past would still be there .
If a fool kept silent , he would be considered wise .
If you were Brianag , you would be the world ’ s sun .
Nam bu tu Brianag bhòidheach , bu tu donnag an t - saoghail .
[See Glossary s . v . Brianag . ]
If the children of the Gaels only knew the value of the tips of the heather , or of the egg of the grouse ,

[The name “ Cailleach Bheithireach ” may be a variant of “ Cailleach Bheur ” — the name of the hag who was thought to have made the Western Isles . See T . M . Murchison ( ed ) , The Prose Writings of Donald Lamont , pp . 199 - 200 ; P . MacCana , Celtic Mythology , pp . 94 - 5 . Cf . J . Grant , Legends of the Braes o ’ Mar , p . 161 . ]
God forbid that I should call him a rogue , but their number will not be complete without Baldy .

[ “ mur bi Donnach ’ ann ’
( HN ) . ]
Death makes poor and makes rich .
The wise man gleans on every field .

There is no theft in the raven ’ s nest which is not to be found in John ’ s heart .
( Skye )
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi . p . 74 . s . v . fitheach . ]
Fresh food and old clothes make a nimble lad .
A dog will snarl over a bone .
Silly will found her hope on the Virgin ’ s crosses .
[See no . 346 . ]
We ’ ll manage without a relative but not without a neighbour .

You swim quietly , like the midges of Shian .
( Benderloch )

A bare house causes a housewife to wander .
( Uist )

Truthful Neil .
( Uist )
The name given ironically to one known to be untruthful . See TGSI , xlv , p . 24 . ]

The black daughter of the soot !
( Uist )

Only a foolish man goes to market without a purse and without cattle .
( Uist )

Whether a MacGiven is young or old , he ’ s untruthful .
( Uist )

A calm , misty night , bright and starry , the wind from the north and the rain from the south , keenly , keenly freezing , and the moon shining steadily on the end of the house .
( Argyll )

[A man had treated his parents meanly by giving them only the liver of a fatted cow . When he asked his mother subsequently what kind of night it was , she gave the reply above . Her son remarked , “ Is iongantach an oidhche th ’ ann ” ( “ It is indeed a strange night ” ) , to which his mother replied , “ Chan eil i nas iongantaiche na am mart - làmhaig a bhith gu léir ’ na grùdha ” ( “ It is no more strange than the fatted cow being all liver ” ) . See TGSI , xlv , pp . 26 - 7 . Cf . N 68 , 5 . ]
It will be paid on Dùn - an - tàilleir market day

May success and grace be yours !
( Argyll )

A new tune on old pipes .
( Uist )

Come , stand still , brindled cow ! You would be better of a fetter !
( Perthshire )

I would go to the top of a hill with him any day .
( Lismore )

May you have the luck of the washing - water !
( Uist )

May good luck without any skill accompany success ! [ ? ]
( Uist )
[Cf . N 49 , 6 ; Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 319 , s . v . rath . ]
He sold his little boy for a little cake .

[ “ airson a bhonnachain ”
( HN ) . ]
He sold his good fortune for a cake .

The birds ’ spring tide .
( Uist )
[Cf . Fr . Allan , p . 200 , s . v . Reothairt mór nan ian . ]

How to satisfy a little child and make him grow : put gruel and milk in his mouth , send him to bed snug and warm , and do not take the cream from his share .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 8 , s . v . anagladh . ]

He made a slavery mouthful of it .
( Argyll )

He made it a subject of continual chatter .
( Argyll )
[Cf . no . 783 above . ]

785 . Ròineag an ìm is càilean am brochan .
A hair in butter and a corn - husk in gruel .
[Cf . BP , no . 232 . ]
The mugginess of Hallowmas .

[This refers to the quiet weather of late Autumn . See Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 120 , s . v .
ròmhanaich ;
Glossary ,
ròmhanaich . ]
The way old women run — downhill .

The horses ’ Sabbath .
( Uist )
789 . Samhradh breac riabhach [còmhla] ris an t - samhradh gheal ghrianach .

A dull , changeable summer as well as a bright , sunny summer .
( Uist )
May you have a long , happy life , and a sound , healthy body ; a cottage which does not leak , and a meal - chest which is ( always ) full .
[Variants of this verse are frequently heard at weddings throughout the Highlands . ]

Leave my head alone and grasp my tail .
( Uist )
[The instructions of a tail - less fox to a wolf which attempted to remove a lamb from a stagnant pit and was in danger of drowning . See TGSI xlv , pp . 27 - 8 . ]
For seven years a cat is lights and playful ; from then on it is a heavy sleepy - head .
[Cf . N 344 , 11 ; Carm . Gad . , ii . p . 322 ; Fr . Allan , p . 144 , s . v . , gollacheannach . ]
The seventeen dogs of Carinish .

The name given to the inhabitants of Carinish in N . Uist by the rest of the Uist people .
