[Cf . no . 735 . ]
[Cf . RC2 , p . 504 ; Dw . s . v . sàth ; Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 322 , s . v . seachd . ]
You show me a skulker and I ’ ll show you a sluggard ( al . a thief ) .
[Cf . Dw . s . v . leisgean . ]
Lochiel ’ s servant .
The willow at streams , the hazel on rocks , the alder at a bog , and the birch at water - falls ; the ash in the shade and the oak in the sun , the lime on the hill , and the yew on the plain .
Show Cream - servant the way to the sheiling .
[A sarcastic remark . One exceptionally fond of cream would know the way to the sheiling . ]
A blessing on the Being .
[C . comments that “ there seems to be a mixture of paganism and Christianity in this saying , heard on the Long Island . ” See Glossary s . v . seun . ]
The lungs of a dog and the lungs of a priest resemble each other .
Spread your sails and the wind will come .
The sloughing of the serpent be yours !
The Skye potato will jump out of its skin to the top of the mast .

[Cf . Dw . s . v .
sgiolc . ]

The vain girl of the ash is the contempt of the village .
( Argyll )
Stop , continue , and keep me a short while yet .

He died as Helen did — in a dark , evil way .
( Skye )

She sat on the toasting - stone .
( Uist )
Ourselves , and ourselves , the MacColls of Glasdruim .
[The form “ Tolla ” is attested in HN , and is probably a dialectal variant of “ Colla ” . ]
Swallow good health , and digest your discomfort without any objection .

Here , here , come and buy ! The thing that cost a shilling yesterday is only three groats today .
( Uist )
The harvest moon which is new on a Saturday will either be a king over seven moons , or it will go mad seven times .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 261 , s . v . Di . ]

Put a wisp on the eye of what is past .
( Uist )
He will smash the treasure - trove with his jaw .
[Sim . Dw . s . v . faodail . ]
Forked purses of the Prince ’ s gold .
Let her wipe herself with the dirty water — it is as good as herself .
When a son stays in his father ’ s house , he is gener -
Women have goats ’ eyes in their heads for choosing men .
Supper is eaten without daylight on St Bridget ’ s night ; supper can be eaten by daylight on St Patrick ’ s Day .
Wooing a woman far from home , when one can be found in the dung - hill pool .
Greed will choke dogs .
[Sim RC2 , p . 505 . ]
Bad weather will meet a man outside , without his taking it from home .
We shall meet again !

A large crop will run out , but a small crop will suffice .
( Skye )
[Sim BP , no . 251 . ]

His boat is afloat .
( Uist )
The Irishman thinks that the gallows is a cross .
[This may mean that the Irishman considers death by hanging to be a noble sacrifice . ]
The Spring day suffers from the fault that one end of it is dry .
[See no . 503 . ]
Her blood and flesh are within her own skin .
Gaelic is easily carried about .

He suffers from fairy - passing .
( Uist )
[Used of paralysis , supposed to have been caused by a fairy in the shape of a dormouse passing over the limb or part affected . See TGSI , xlv , p . 28 . ]
The tune corresponds to the foot .
Marriage is like a bee — it contains both honey and a sting .

The wicked man crosses the ferry in a broken boat on a dark , stormy Winter night .
( Uist )

The ford has to be crossed there and back .
( Uist )
Truth is sometimes a beast .
The Pleiades lose their course nine nights before Christmas .

Everything has one end , but a pudding has two .
( Perthshire )

You got very little for nothing .
( Uist )
[i . e . , you made a bad bargain . ]
There is a spit of wood through his tongue .
There are MacKenzies and MacKenzies .
[i . e . it is unwise to generalise . ]
There are five kinds of fools ; you belong to the fifth kind .

i . e . , to the worst kind .
[Cf . N 358 , 2 . ]
There are dogs of the canine species , and dogs of the human species .
You carry the lazy lad ’ s burden .
[i . e . , a very light burden . Cf . RC2 , p . 506 ; BP , no . 267 . ]
There are two sides to the headland and seven different views of it .
[i . e . , there are several different ways of seeing the same thing . In Argyll , the headland is taken to be the Mull of Kintyre . Cf . N 356 , 6 ; RC2 , p . 506 . ]
A poor man pays dearly even for a night ’ s sleep . [Sim . Dw . s . v . daor . ]
Our own great god of the Camerons is coming home , and thieving will begin just as it always was .
[After the translation , C . adds in brackets , “ Mary MacKellar ” . ]

There ’ s a way of doing everything ; there ’ s a way of sowing barley .
( Argyll )

Man and beast are liable to twenty - four diseases ; a disease for every hour of the day .
( Hebrides )
A man ’ s fault is as big as a hill before he sees it himself .
It is too big to be a lazy - bed and too small to be a croft .

There are many who know John the Fool .
( Skye )

The fisherman ’ s hands are cleaner than those of the dairy - maid .
( Skye )

There ’ s a calf which can be killed .
( Argyll )

(
“ Tha laogh bó ann ”
( HN ) . ]

I am without it , as Barbreck was without a piper .
( Argyll )

[Used when a person lacks anything which should normally be in his possession . The Laird of Barbreck was reputedly too mean to keep a piper , and on one occasion asked the piper of his relative , the Laird of of Craignish , to play for him . See TGSI , xlv , p . 29 . ]

I am middling .
( Badenoch )
Tha mi ’ n eatorras mar tha ’ m baile ’ m Bàideanach .
[This is Etteridge in English . MacBain gives the Gaelic form “ Eatrais ” . See TGSI , xvi , p . 195 . ]

The fairies are churning .
( Uist )
[It was believed that on certain days of the week , the fairies could be heard churning the weekly supply of milk in the knoll . See TGSI , xlv , p . 30 . ]
The first man ( in the boat ) has his choice of the oars .

That is as moderate as Big Donald ’ s scallop - shell .
( Harris )
A funeral barge has a peaceful passage .

There is an unused pot - hanger in MacUisdein ’ s house .
( Uist )
[Attributed to a Uist man , MacUisdein , who was unable to give his retainers their usual Christmas Day meal of seal flesh because of stormy weather . See TGSI , xlv , p . 31 . ]

Every saint has his own light .
( Uist )

I have that in spite of the hounds which have the fodder .
( Skye )

Men have a goat ’ s eye as regards women , and women have a hawk ’ s eye as regards men .
[Cf . no . 817 . ]

You are just the same , Staring - eye , you are just the same .
( Skye )
There ’ s a bush in the gateway .
[Sim . Dw . , s . v . tom . )
She suffered the same fate as the cat that went to the waterfall .
[i . e . , she got into trouble . Cf . N 348 , 7 . ]
i . e . , it reached extremity .
I escaped from Ciogan and I escaped from Cuaigean ; I escaped from Leaca - bonnaich , and I escaped from behind the door ; and if I may , I ’ ll escape from you .

[According to Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 285 , s . v . Geigean ,
this was used by boys at play . ]
The Devil came to St Columba ; he heard St Columba converse with One not present ; the Devil fled .
It ’ s as well to go over the socks as over the shoes .
A sigh goes farther than a cry .

An adder will go through red - hot fire sooner than through the leaves of the ash .
( Mull )
Bad times come upon the houses of lords .

Sleep will come unsought , though gold will not .
( Uist )

A whisper will come above board .
( Uist )
A dun , hornless cow will appear in the Minch and let out a bellow which will smash the six windows of Gairloch House .
[Cf . A . MacKenzie , The Prophecies of the Brahan Seer , pp 20 - 1 . ]
People have spread a bad story about me and about you , virtuous Malcolm !
[Cf . J . C . Watson ( ed . ) , Gaelic Songs of Mary MacLeod , p . 14 , ll . 147 - 8 . ]
Punch a full sack .
Give in to superstitions , and you will continue to give in to superstitions .
Take your plaid with you on a dry day ; on a wet day , do as you like .
Report back as you have heard .
He derived his sustenance from the stone anchor .
[i . e . , he lived by fishing . See Glossary s . v . cruaidh . ]

You have brought Winter with you !
( Inverness district )
His fan and his strap fell off him .
[C . ’ s translation is doubtful . Cf . Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 78 , s . v . gaid . ]
Ben Nevis has fallen — and I knew that would happen by its swaying last night .
Tyndrum is a nasty village , where no one ever got enough to eat ; I got meat there , and a saw wouldn ’ t cut it , and my teeth couldn ’ t penetrate a bit of the cheese .
A house without a thief is a house without equipment .
[i . e . , a house without anything which can be stolen . See Glossary s . v . iomasglachadh . ]

A house without prayer is like a house without thatch .
( Inverness district )

Throw a bone to the Devil .
( Uist )

A Tiree man , with the company ’ s leave .
( Uist )
The virtuous well of Tibberton .

Tobar Thiobartain nam buadh
A chaisgeas gach failc agus fual ,
An eilean iomartach a ’ chuain ,
Am fìor iomall an domhain mhóir .
[Cf . Carm . Gad . , ii , p . 273 , s . v . falc . See Glossary s . v . failc and fual . ]
The dowry of O ’ Cahan ’ s Daughter .
[See TGSI , xlv , p . 32 , where her dowry is given as :
Naoi cipeanan , naoi naoi teadhair ri gach cipean , agus bó air gach teadhair , agus tarbh agus buachaille air gach cipean .

Agnes , daughter of Guy O ’ Cahan of Ulster , married Angus Og of the Isles about 1300 ( A . MacDonald and A . MacDonald , Clan Donald . iii . p . 180 ; W . Nicolaisen ( ed . ) , Proceedings of the Third International Congress of Celtic Studies , p . 6l ) . ]
The harvest will look after itself .
This implies that harvest depends on factors beyond man ’ s control [and , presumably , that it will not fail] . It refers also to the cheery nature of harvest work .
The fool builds a house ; the wise man dwells in it .

It is more profitable to buy a house than to build one . [The saying probably means that a fool doesn ’ t stay in the house after he has built it . Cf . Dw . s . v . gliocaire . “ caisteal ” ( i . e . castle ) for “ tigh ” ( HN ) . ]

We lift our empty hands to heaven and God lays work upon them .
( Lorn )
Smoke , cold and a nagging wife — out goes the man .
Plough the lea land to the gravel .
[See Glossary s . v . dil . ]
Three beautiful things : a ship under sail , a tree in bloom , and a godly man on his death - bed .
Three honourable things : reverence for the Trinity , reverence for the clergy , and reverence for old age .

The farmer ’ s three nights : the night the stackyard is filled , the night the plough is put into the dunghill ( for preservation ) and the night the rent is paid .
( Perthshire )
The bard ’ s three privileges are : a raven ’ s foreknowledge of a feast , a generous invitation to compose verses , and a mighty thirst for drinking his dram .
[Cf . N 185 , 9 ; 372 , 4 ; Carm . Gad . , vi , p . 73 , s . v . fios fithich . ]
The three terrors of the world are : wind for blowing , sea for roaring , fire for total destruction .

The mongrel - pup ’ s scolding of the little dog .
( Perthshire )

Trod an fharra - mheasain…
The mock - pup ’ s scolding…
Tuaileam and Taileam .
[The Gaelic equivalent of “ Tweedledum and Tweedledee ” . ]
The horse ’ s wages are its food .

More strength to your elbow ! Man , sit up !
( Perthshire )
The wood - gatherer ’ s hour is added to the day on St Bridget ’ s Day .

The Devil ’ s egg .
( Argyll )
[Applied to anything that would bring bad luck or disturb a peaceful gathering . The “ Devil ’ s egg ” was the thirteenth egg which merchants claimed to make a dozen . See TGSI , xlv , p . 32 . ]

An egg seeking a pullet .
( Mull )
Hen ’ s eggs , pigs ’ flesh , men ’ s praise — the dearest purchase there is .
Uist of the generous people .
The prayer of the thatch .
A fuss before childbirth .

Croisean - Moire the Virgin ’ s crosses 346 , 763 . C . explains that the reference is to gossamer , and cites an English legend ( so far untraced ) “ that gossamer is the ravellings of the Virgin Mary ’ s winding sheet , which fell away on her ascension into heaven . ” This seems improbable . The Rev . A . MacDonald , Killearnan , who also noted saying 346 , states that it is evidently of Protestant origin “ meaning that devotion to a cross is trifling and mere child ’ s play . ”
